case_name: Lalji Haridas v. Income-tax Officer, Ward D, Jamnagar & Union of India

facts.text: Appeal by special leave arises out of writ petition filed by appellant Lalji Haridas in High Court of Gujarat under article 226

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave arises out of a writ petition filed by the appellant, Lalji Haridas, in the High Court of Gujarat under article 226 of the Constitution

facts.text: Writ petition prayed for certiorari against Income-tax Officer Ward D Jamnagar and Union of India

anchor.surface_text: in which he prayed for a writ including a writ in the nature of certiorari against respondent No. 1, the Income-tax Officer, Ward D, Jamnagar, as well as the respondent No. 2, the Union of India,

facts.text: Two notices issued by ITO against appellant on 14th April 1960 and 7th July 1960

anchor.surface_text: quashing two numberices issued by the respondent No. 1 against him on the 14th April, 1960, and the 7th July, 1960.

facts.text: Assessment order passed by ITO against appellant on 17th December 1958

anchor.surface_text: He also prayed that the assessment order passed against him by the Income-tax Officer on the 17th December, 1958, should likewise be quashed.

facts.text: High Court dismissed writ petition in limine without issuing notice to respondents

anchor.surface_text: This petition was dismissed by the High Court in limine without issuing numberice to the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court against HC dismissal

anchor.surface_text: Against the dismissal of his petition, the appellant applied for and obtained special leave from this companyrt and it was with this special leave thus granted to him

facts.text: Appellant is resident of Jamnagar

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the resident of Jamnagar and the order of the assessment was passed against him on 17th December, 1958,

facts.text: Assessment order on 17th December 1958 assessing Rs. 4,74,046 income tax

anchor.surface_text: assessing him to pay income-tax on Rs. 4,74,046. Before making this order of assessment, numberice has been issued

facts.text: Notice issued to appellant on 20th December 1957 under section 46(1)(a) of Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance 1949

anchor.surface_text: Before making this order of assessment, numberice has been issued against the appellant on 20th December, 1957, under section 46 1   a  of Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949.

facts.text: Notice for assessment year 1949-50 as large amount of income escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: This section companyresponds to section 34 1   a  of Indian Income-tax Act. It appears that respondent No. 1 came to known that for the assessment year 1949-50, a large amount of income received by the appellant had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Appellant made return showing income of Rs. 46 for the year

anchor.surface_text: That is why numberice was issued against him calling upon him to make a return of his income for the relevant year. The appellant thereupon made a return showing an income of Rs. 46 for the year in question.

facts.text: Several amounts credited in appellant's account books representing income

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 had companye to know that several amounts had been credited in the account books of the appellant and appeared to represent his income.

facts.text: On 24th October 1948, two sums of Rs. 1 lakh each credited: Ms. Bhagirath Madangopal Co., Bombay and Mulji Manilal Kamdar

anchor.surface_text: On the 24th October, 1948, for instance two sums of Rs. 1 lakh each had been credited in the names of M s. Bhagirath Madangopal Co., Bombay, and Mulji Manilal Kamdar respectively.

facts.text: Mulji Manilal Kamdar amount subsequently transferred to Ms. Bhagirath Kasat Co.

anchor.surface_text: The latter amount was subsequently transferred to the account of another firm of M s. Bhagirath Kasat Co.

facts.text: On 7th March 1949, Rs. 1,80,000 transferred to the company

anchor.surface_text: On the 7th March, 1949, another sum of Rs. 1,80,000 was transferred to the said companypany.

facts.text: Further credits of Rs. 74,000 and Rs. 20,000 discovered

anchor.surface_text: Further credits to the tune of Rs. 74,000 and Rs. 20,000 were also discovered.

facts.text: Appellant claimed credits were benami transactions not his income

anchor.surface_text: In submitting his return, the appellant attempted to say that these amounts did number represent his income at all and showed benami transactions entered into by him on behalf of other persons.

facts.text: ITO not satisfied with explanation and passed assessment order

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 1 was number satisfied with the explanation given by the appellant, and so he passed the order of assessment as indicated above.

facts.text: Appellant appealed assessment to Appellate Assistant Commissioner Rajkot

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of assessment, the appellant preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Rajkot.

facts.text: AAC partly accepted contentions, remanded on 3rd September 1959 to examine witnesses

anchor.surface_text: The appellate authority partly accepted his companytention and by its order passed on the 3rd September, 1959, it remanded the proceedings to respondent No. 1 and directed him to submit a report after examining the witness

facts.text: AAC commented appellant adopting dilatory proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Even while making this order of remand, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companymented on the fact that the appellant appeared to be determined to adopt dilatory proceedings

facts.text: After remand, letters dated 13th April 1960 and 7th July 1960 to appellant to appear and give evidence

anchor.surface_text: After the matter was thus remanded to respondent No. 1, the appellant was required by two letters dated 13th April, 1960, and 7th July, 1960, to appear before respondent No. 1 and give his evidence.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in Gujarat High Court on 9th July 1960 instead of complying

anchor.surface_text: Instead of companyplying with the requisition companytained in the said letters, the appellant moved the Gujarat High Court of the 9th July, 1960, by his present writ petition.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal from remand order to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: It appears that he also preferred an appeal from the remand order to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: High Court summarily rejected writ petition

anchor.surface_text: The High Court summarily rejected the writ petition filed by the appellant,
under article 226 of the Constitution
a writ including a writ in the nature of certiorari against respondent No. 1, the Income-tax Officer, Ward D, Jamnagar, as well as the respondent No. 2,

concepts.unlisted_description: Assessment order claimed as null and void

issues.text: Whether the notice issued against the appellant under section 46(1)(a) of Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance, 1949 is invalid as barred by time

anchor.surface_text: the notice issued against the appellant, is on the face of it, invalid, because it is barred by time. We did not allow Mr. Pathak to develop this point, because we took the view that a plea of this kind must ordinarily taken before respondent No. 1 himself.

issues.text: Whether the Appellate Assistant Commissioner ought to have treated the assessment order as a nullity and set it aside instead of remanding the case

anchor.surface_text: Appellant Assistant Commissioner had instead of treating the assessment order a nullity and having the same set aside, illegally remanded the case back to the Income-tax Officer to save limitation. It would be noticed that at its highest, this ground can mean that the result of the remand order was to attempt to save limitation

issues.text: Whether the assessment order passed on 17th December, 1958 was in the nature of a protective assessment and should be set aside

anchor.surface_text: was in the nature of levy of protective assessment, and so it should be set aside. This point again ought to be raised before the Income-tax Officer and cannot be allowed to be urged before the High Court under article 226.

issues.text: Whether writ jurisdiction under Article 226 can be invoked to challenge tax notices and assessment orders on grounds like limitation, nullity or protective nature, bypassing alternative remedies before Income-tax authorities

anchor.surface_text: under article 226 is not intended to supersede the jurisdiction and authority of the Income-tax Officers to deal with the merits of all the contentions that the assessees may raise before them, and so it would be entirely inappropriate to permit an assessee to move the High Court under the article 226

issues.text: Whether the Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance under which proceedings were commenced is invalid

anchor.surface_text: From the petition for special leave, it would appear that at the time of admission, the appellant presumably urged before this court that the Saurashtra Income-tax Ordinance under which the present proceedings had been commenced against him was invalid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Point to be raised before ITO; cannot be urged in Art 226; plea vague, not on oath

arguments.claim: Jurisdiction under Article 226 not intended to supersede Income-tax authorities' jurisdiction on merits like limitation

anchor.surface_text: The jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under article 226 is not intended to supersede the jurisdiction and authority of the Income-tax Officers to deal with the merits of all the contentions that the assessees may raise before them, and so it would be entirely inappropriate to permit an assessee to move the High Court under the article 226

arguments.claim: Appellant is adopting dilatory proceedings to prolong assessment

anchor.surface_text: In fact, this appeal illustrates how an assessee can prolong the assessment proceedings by adopting judicial proceedings available to him under the law and thereby postpone indefinitely the final disposal of the said proceedings by the income- tax authorities.

arguments.claim: Writ petition should be dismissed in limine

anchor.surface_text: This petition was dismissed by the High Court in limine without issuing notice to the respondents.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court in limine without issuing numberice to the respondents. Against the dismissal of his petition, the appellant applied for and obtained

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court granted special leave but ultimately dismissed appeal

arguments.claim: Appeal has no substance and must be dismissed with costs

anchor.surface_text: Having heard Mr. Pathak on behalf of the appellant, we have come to the conclusion that there is no substance in this appeal and it must be dismissed with the costs.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under article 226 is not intended to supersede the jurisdiction and authority of the Income-tax Officers to deal with the merits of all the contentions that the assessees may raise before them, and so it would be entirely inappropriate to permit an assessee to move the High Court under the article 226 and contend that a notice issued against him is barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: under article 226 is not intended to supersede the jurisdiction and authority of the Income-tax Officers to deal with the merits of all the contentions that the assessees may raise before them, and so it would be entirely inappropriate to permit an assessee to move the High Court under the article 226 and contend that a notice issued against him is barred by time.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 226 writ jurisdiction exists alongside but does not override tax authorities' power to adjudicate merits-based pleas like limitation; assessees must exhaust statutory remedies.

holdings.text: We did not allow Mr. Pathak to develop this point, because we took the view that a plea of this kind must ordinarily taken before respondent No. 1 himself.

anchor.surface_text: We did not allow Mr. Pathak to develop this point, because we took the view that a plea of this kind must ordinarily taken before respondent No. 1 himself. The jurisdiction conferred on the High Court under article 226 is not intended to supersede the jurisdiction and authority of the Income-tax Officers to deal with the merits of all the contentions that the assessees may raise before them,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea that notice is barred by time is a merits issue for Income-tax Officer; writ court will not entertain without exhaustion of alternative remedy.

holdings.text: This point again ought to be raised before the Income-tax Officer and cannot be allowed to be urged before the High Court under article 226.

anchor.surface_text: This point again ought to be raised before the Income-tax Officer and cannot be allowed to be urged before the High Court under article 226. Even in respect of this point, the plea taken is extremely vague and the appellant has not even stated on oath that other persons have in fact paid assessment in respect of transactions which respondent No. 1 regards as his.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Claim of protective assessment is a factual/merits contention to be urged before tax authorities, not via writ petition.

holdings.text: a plea of this kind cannot be permitted to be raised in writ proceedings

anchor.surface_text: But, as we have already indicated, a plea of this kind cannot be permitted to be raised in writ proceedings, and so we refused Mr. Pathak permission to develop this point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Argument that Appellate Assistant Commissioner erred by remanding instead of declaring assessment nullity is a procedural/merits plea for tax hierarchy, not writ court.

holdings.text: Having heard Mr. Pathak on behalf of the appellant, we have come to the conclusion that there is no substance in this appeal and it must be dismissed with the costs.

anchor.surface_text: Having heard Mr. Pathak on behalf of the appellant, we have come to the conclusion that there is no substance in this appeal and it must be dismissed with the costs. In fact, this appeal illustrates how an assessee can prolong the assessment proceedings by adopting judicial proceedings available to him under the law and thereby postpone indefinitely the final disposal of the said proceedings by the income- tax authorities.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All petitioner contentions inappropriate for writ jurisdiction; High Court rightly dismissed petition in limine.
